flow.context: Alexander Vega is General Manager at Oranj Palm Vacation Homes — the vacation rental arm of Palm Springs Rental Agency, operating since 1972 in the Coachella Valley. He has 18+ years of management experience and oversees cross-functional operations including their QA department, maintenance, and turnover workflows across 100+ properties on Track PMS. They already use OpenAI on their website for review summarization so they're not AI-averse, but no inspection platform like Breezeway is confirmed — that's the gap. February is peak season in Palm Springs, meaning turnover volume and QA pressure are at their highest right now. Sam's angle is SoCal native — grew up in the LA area, knows the desert market — and credibility from working with similar vacation rental operators.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Alexander — I've been working with a few vacation rental managers out in the desert, and your name came up. Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around?
opener.note: Feet up energy. Smile. 'The desert' is how SoCal locals refer to Palm Springs area — signals you know the market. Don't rush the question at the end.

heard_name_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_name_yes.say: Oh nice — well we've been working with a few property managers in the Coachella Valley on their inspection stuff. What'd you hear?
heard_name_yes.note: Shut up and listen. Whatever they say, mirror it back. Don't correct them. If they're vague, pivot naturally to the pain trigger.

heard_name_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD OF YOU
heard_name_no.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason I'm calling — I work with a few other GMs running vacation rental portfolios similar to yours, and I wanted to run something by you real quick.
heard_name_no.note: Self-deprecating line breaks tension. Transition smoothly into the pain — don't pause too long between the joke and the pivot.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? Maybe Thursday or Friday afternoon?
bad_timing.note: Suggest specific days. Don't ask open-ended 'when works.' Peak season means he's slammed — respect that and keep it tight.

branches.label: Just tell me real quick now

bad_timing_reschedule.label: CALLBACK LOCKED
bad_timing_reschedule.say: Perfect — I'll try you Thursday around two. Talk then, Alexander.
bad_timing_reschedule.note: Say the specific day and time back. Keep it tight and get off the phone — don't overstay your welcome. Log the callback immediately.

gatekeeper_slide.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper_slide.say: Hey — could you get me through to Alexander? It's Sam.
gatekeeper_slide.note: First name only. No company name. No explanation. Sound like you belong. This could be Brenda Lopez (Executive Assistant at OPVH) — if she identifies herself, use her name going forward.

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other vacation rental companies in Palm Springs on their inspection workflows. Would you mind letting Alexander know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Don't pitch RapidEye. Don't explain what it does. Just enough to sound legitimate. If this is Brenda, say her name: 'Hey Brenda — would you mind letting Alexander know?'

branches.label: Can you tell me more first?

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally — we help a couple property management companies out here with their QA and turnover workflows. I actually sent Alexander a note about it. Would you mind giving him a heads up that I called?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: 'Sent a note' is true if you emailed Alexander@oranjpalm.com before calling. Always end with a redirect question — you ask, you control.

gatekeeper_dead_end.label: GATEKEEPER — DEAD END
gatekeeper_dead_end.say: Appreciate it — and who am I speaking with, just so I know? ... Thanks. I'll follow up with an email to Alexander. Have a good one.
gatekeeper_dead_end.note: Get their name. If it's Brenda Lopez, note it for your next attempt. Send follow-up email to Alexander@oranjpalm.com today referencing the call.

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION ASK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah, totally fair — I mean it is a cold call. Can I get thirty seconds to tell you why I reached out? And if it's not relevant you can totally hang up on me.
permission_fallback.note: Disarm with radical honesty. The 'hang up on me' line gives them control, which paradoxically makes them more likely to listen.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION DENIED — SPLIT
permission_rejected.say: Shoot — totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it more that you already know what we do and it's just not interesting?
permission_rejected.note: The multiple-choice question re-engages them. You're asking them to diagnose the rejection, which often reopens the door.

branches.label: Not interested / know what you do

permission_split_response.label: CAPTURE EMAIL — EXIT GRACEFULLY
permission_split_response.say: Totally get it. Look — I'll shoot you a quick email so you have my info in case anything changes. Is Alexander@oranjpalm.com the best address?
permission_split_response.note: Confirm the inferred email. Don't push further — you've planted the seed. Send a personalized email within the hour.

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: So I was talking to another GM — runs about a hundred vacation rentals, pretty similar setup to you guys — and he was telling me that no matter how dialed in his QA team was, stuff was still slipping through between turnovers. A guest checks in, finds a cracked tile or a stained comforter that three people supposedly signed off on, and now he's got a one-star review and an owner calling asking what happened. His team was taking photos every single turnover — the problem was nobody actually had time to go through all of them. Does any of that ring a bell, or is your world totally different?
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after 'or is your world totally different.' Count to three in your head. The silence is where the magic happens. Do not fill it. February is peak season in Palm Springs so this pain is especially acute right now.

branches.label: We have a QA process for that

pain_engaged.label: THEY FEEL THE PAIN — DISCOVER
pain_engaged.say: Yeah — what does that look like on your end? When something does slip through, how does it usually come to your attention?
pain_engaged.note: They're warm. STOP PITCHING. Ask questions. Let them talk about their pain in their own words. Mirror what they say back. Take notes — you'll use these specifics in the meeting.

pain_not_engaged.label: PAIN DIDN'T LAND — REFRAME
pain_not_engaged.say: That's honestly great to hear — if you've got it locked down, that's better than most. Out of curiosity, how are you guys handling the photo review side of turnovers right now? Is that something your QA team does manually for every property, or do you have something automated?
pain_not_engaged.note: Don't push. Reframe as genuine curiosity. This question either reveals a hidden gap or confirms they're truly not a fit. Either answer teaches you something.

branches.label: We're all set / don't need anything
Actually, we do have some issues...

discovery_process.label: DISCOVERY — CURRENT WORKFLOW
discovery_process.say: Got it. And when your team takes turnover photos — is that all running through Track, or is that a separate workflow?
discovery_process.note: You know they use Track PMS. Namedropping it shows real homework and earns credibility. Listen for what ops or inspection tool they use — that tells you exactly where the gap is.

branches.label: How'd you know we use Track?

discovery_qa_followup.label: DISCOVERY — QA DEPTH
discovery_qa_followup.say: Makes sense. And I know you guys have a QA department — is that team actually reviewing every set of photos from every turnover, or is it more of a spot-check thing?
discovery_qa_followup.note: You know they have a QA department (QA@oranjpalm.com is published). This question exposes the real gap — even a dedicated QA team can't manually review every photo from 100+ properties every turnover cycle.

branches.label: Honestly we're not great at reviewing photos

solution_one_liner.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION
solution_one_liner.say: That's exactly why I reached out. We built a tool that plugs right into Track and automatically analyzes every turnover photo your team's already taking — catches damage, missing items, staging issues — before the guest ever walks in. No workflow change on your end.
solution_one_liner.note: ONE sentence about the solution. Then STOP. Let the silence do the work. Don't list features. Don't oversell. If they ask 'how does it work' — save details for the meeting.

branches.label: I'd need to run that by Thomas or Karlos

cta_meeting.label: ASK FOR THE MEETING
cta_meeting.say: Would you be open to taking a quick look when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue? I can walk you through what a couple other property managers in the desert are doing with their turnover photos — worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
cta_meeting.note: 'Steal some ideas' reframes the meeting as valuable even if they never buy. The only goal right now is getting on his calendar — nothing else matters.

branches.label: I'd need to loop in leadership first

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next Tuesday and Thursday pulled up — which one works better for you? Morning or afternoon?
book_meeting.note: Two options, not open-ended. Lock day AND time. If they hesitate, pick for them: 'How about Thursday at ten?'

branches.label: Not sure of my schedule — email me

meeting_confirmed.label: MEETING BOOKED
meeting_confirmed.say: Perfect — I'll send over a calendar invite right now so it's locked in. Really appreciate you taking my call, Alexander. Talk soon.
meeting_confirmed.note: Send the invite WHILE still on the phone. Then get off. Don't keep selling — you already won. Log everything he said for meeting prep.

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Totally hear you — you're probably not buying anything off a cold call today, and I respect that. But honestly, when timing does open up, the people who jump on stuff like this are usually the ones who already know what's out there. Would you be open to a fifteen-minute look — no strings, just so it's on your radar?
sell_test_drive.note: Reframe the meeting as intelligence-gathering, not a purchase decision. 'Fifteen minutes' is low commitment. If this doesn't land, pivot to email or referral.

branches.label: I'm not really the right person for this

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool than buy a new one, let alone add something to the stack.
objection_no_budget.note: Agree first. Don't fight it. Let the agreement land before you move to the split question.

branches.label: It's not really about budget — we're just not looking

objection_budget_split.label: BUDGET — SPLIT QUESTION
objection_budget_split.say: Just so nobody from my team keeps cold calling you on this — is it that budget this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything new has to get the OK from Thomas and Karlos first?
objection_budget_split.note: Namedropping Thomas (President) and Karlos (VP) shows you know the org structure. It also reveals the real blocker — budget timing vs. approval chain.

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it — honestly, I should've assumed you'd be all set. Otherwise you probably would've reached out yourself.
objection_not_interested.note: Agree completely. Don't push back at all. The goal is to use the agreement to reopen with the split question.

branches.label: Yeah so... (wants to end the call)

objection_interest_split.label: INTEREST — SPLIT QUESTION
objection_interest_split.say: Just so I know — is it that turnover quality genuinely isn't a headache for you guys right now, or is it more that you just hate getting cold calls?
objection_interest_split.note: Say this with a smile in your voice — the second option usually gets a laugh and reopens the conversation. If they say 'both,' laugh with them and pivot to the test drive.

branches.label: We're honestly doing fine on that front
Ha — I do hate cold calls
It is a pain but we handle it in-house

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — ALREADY HAVE QA PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with a hundred-plus properties and a whole QA department, you'd have to have something dialed in. I'd honestly be surprised if you didn't.
objection_have_process.note: Validate their investment in quality. Don't challenge their process. Referencing their unit count and dedicated QA team shows you've done real homework on Oranj Palm.

branches.label: I mean it's not perfect but...

objection_process_split.label: QA PROCESS — SPLIT QUESTION
objection_process_split.say: Totally fair. Is it that your current setup catches pretty much everything and you're happy with it, or is it more that adding or changing anything right now would just be a headache?
objection_process_split.note: This split separates 'truly solved' from 'switching cost anxiety.' Most people fall into the second bucket, which is your opening to position a no-workflow-change solution.

branches.label: Changing anything would be a headache
What would it even look like to add something?

needs_boss_approval.label: NEEDS LEADERSHIP APPROVAL
needs_boss_approval.say: Makes total sense — is it usually Thomas or Karlos who'd green-light something like this? I don't want to put you in a weird position.
needs_boss_approval.note: Thomas Salinas is President, Karlos Salinas is VP. Naming them shows you understand their org. If Alexander offers to intro you, that's gold — take it immediately.

branches.label: Yeah, one of them would decide
Let me check with them first and get back to you
Actually I can probably make this call myself

referral_from_alexander.label: BRIDGE TO LEADERSHIP
referral_from_alexander.say: Would it help if I put together something specific you could forward to them? Or even better — would you be open to a quick fifteen minutes where I walk all three of us through it? That way you're not stuck playing telephone.
referral_from_alexander.note: Push for the group meeting first — Alexander plus Thomas or Karlos. If not, get permission to email leadership directly using Alexander's name as your intro.

branches.label: Just send me something I can forward
I'll talk to them and let you know

book_meeting_with_caveat.label: PENCIL IN FOLLOW-UP
book_meeting_with_caveat.say: Totally — how about this: let's pencil in fifteen minutes later this week. You check with them, and if the timing's off, no hard feelings — we just reschedule. How's Thursday afternoon look?
book_meeting_with_caveat.note: Don't let it float into 'I'll get back to you' limbo. Pin a specific day. 'Pencil in' reduces commitment anxiety. At minimum walk away with a firm callback window.

send_email_request.label: THEY WANT AN EMAIL
send_email_request.say: Totally fair. One quick question before I do — what would be most helpful to include so it doesn't just sit in your inbox like every other vendor pitch?
send_email_request.note: This question reveals what they actually care about — use their answer to tailor the email. It also keeps the conversation going and shows you're not just blasting templates.

email_tailor.label: CONFIRM EMAIL AND PIN FOLLOW-UP
email_tailor.say: Got it — I'll put something together around that and get it to you today. Is Alexander@oranjpalm.com the best address? And just so I'm not chasing you — would early next week be a fair time to follow up, or is there a better window?
email_tailor.note: You inferred Alexander@oranjpalm.com from their published firstname@ email convention. Confirm it. Pin a specific follow-up day — never leave it open-ended.

branches.label: Gives different email or different timing

email_sent.label: EMAIL CONFIRMED — CLOSE
email_sent.say: Perfect — I'll get that over to you today. Appreciate your time, Alexander. Talk soon.
email_sent.note: Send the email within one hour. Include something specific from the conversation. Suggest a concrete meeting time in the email. Follow up on the exact day they agreed to.

referral_ask.label: REFERRAL — WHO OWNS THIS?
referral_ask.say: Totally understand. Out of curiosity — who on your team usually owns the inspection and turnover quality workflow day-to-day? Is that Lucia on the ops side, or does that sit somewhere else?
referral_ask.note: Lucia Macklis is Operations Manager — dropping her name makes it easy for Alexander to confirm or redirect. If he says it's more of a leadership call, pivot to needs_boss_approval.

branches.label: That's really more of a Thomas or Karlos decision

referral_name.label: REFERRAL — GET PERMISSION
referral_name.say: Got it — would you mind if I reached out to them and mentioned we chatted? I'll keep it super tailored so it's actually relevant and not just another cold pitch.
referral_name.note: Get explicit permission to use Alexander's name. This transforms your next call from cold to warm — massive difference in conversion rate.

referral_close.label: REFERRAL SECURED
referral_close.say: Really appreciate that, Alexander. I'll keep it relevant — won't waste their time. Thanks for pointing me the right direction. Have a good one.
referral_close.note: Email the referral TODAY. Lead with 'I was just talking with Alexander and he suggested I reach out to you about your turnover workflow.' Log everything from this call.

graceful_end.label: END GRACEFULLY
graceful_end.say: Totally understand. Hey — if anything changes down the road, I'm easy to find. Appreciate your time, Alexander.
graceful_end.note: Don't burn the bridge. Log the call, note the objection reason, and circle back in 6-8 weeks with fresh value — a case study, new market data, or a relevant trigger event.
